summary: Henry P. Lopez was a CIA asset who worked for the Mexico City Station from 1961 to 1966. Documents detail his activities, expenses, and cover arrangements with the CIA, including the use of proprietary companies. He was also connected to Edward G. Tichborn in operational activities in Spain and contract work with the CIA. Later, he was employed as a legal consultant for WUSALINE in New York City. In 1978, the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) requested CIA assistance to interview Lopez in Mexico, indicating his potential relevance to the JFK assassination investigation.
significance: Henry P. Lopez's significance in the JFK context stems from the HSCA's interest in interviewing him in 1978, suggesting he may have had information relevant to the assassination. His prior work as a CIA asset in Mexico City during the early 1960s, a period of interest in the JFK assassination investigation, further underscores his potential relevance.
